newsitem.title: COLOMBIA: Federation to retain control over Colombian coffee.
newsitem.headline: Federation to retain control over Colombian coffee.

text.p: The National Coffee Growers' Federation will maintain its authoritarian-style control over Colombia's coffee industry for at least another decade, Bogota El Tiempo newspaper reported Monday.
The daily, citing unidentified industry sources, said the federation was on the verge of signing a new contract with the government that would leave its sweeping powers intact for another decade.
The federation's current 10-year contract with the government expires in December 1998.

One of the few changes in the new contract would allow the federation to obtain credits, at home or abroad, without previous authorization from the policy-making board of directors of Colombia's central bank, according to El Tiempo.

Finance Minister Jose Antonio Ocampo confirmed in remarks to reporters last week that negotiations were under way to draw up terms of a new federation operating contract. But he declined further comment other than to say that the contract had to be signed before a deadline sometime in July.
Federation spokesmen could not be reached for immediate comment.

But El Tiempo said the new contract, hammered out in talks over the last few months, essentially threw a growing chorus of calls by private exporters for the deregulation of Colombia's coffee trade out the window.

It said the federation, together with the government- controlled National Coffee Fund, would continue to control physical supplies by setting monthly limits on exports and it would remain the final arbiter when it comes to deciding prices paid to domestic growers.
